segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 All right, so yeah, we're going to do some dark web, dark net, deep web, dark, dark stuff.
But also there's going to be a lot of throwback.
So for those who were around for BBSs and IRC and Usenet and all of that, you guys can
have some fun, too.
So a little bit about myself.
My name, as she said, is Benjamin Brown.
I work for Akamai Technologies.
There I mostly focus on dark web, cybercrime and underground economy research.
And I also do advanced training.
I do incident response both internally for the company, for security incidents, but also
for our customers when they're under DDoS or somebody's trying to do an account check
or campaign or something like that.
Also I get to be a general chaos monkey around the company, which is a lot of fun.
Without the network owners or the product owners knowing it or expecting it, I can at
any point just go in and wreck their shit and then come back, you know, and help them
make it more resilient, which is a lot of fun.
So setting the framework for this talk, what is going to be in scope is anything to do
with e-banking, e-commerce, digital currencies, digital marketplaces and digital economies.
What I'm not really going to be talking a whole lot about, in case you see gaps in some
of the history, it's because I'm not looking at general freaking, cracking, hacking.
And I'm mostly focusing on electronic, economic or financial transaction-related crime.
So we'll start out with some definitions.
The media likes to use all three of these interchangeably, but they do have distinct
definitions.
And I found this graphic is a great way to explain it for the year 2003.
Now that there are a number of different emerging dark net frameworks, and these are, you know,
the network topology frameworks and the sets of protocols for the dark nets, there tends
to be more and more overlay dark webs on top of that.
And the dark web would be, like, where you actually have a website component instead
of just, like, file sharing or encrypted databases on a dark net or something like that.
And then, of course, all of these are overlay networks, so they'll be laying on top of
the internet.
I'm not really going to go into ad hoc mesh networks, that can be a whole separate talk.
These are all networks that sit on top of the internet itself as we know it.
All right.
So we're going to start way, way, way back in the beginning of electronic ‑‑ financially
motivated electronic crime with literal wire fraud.
So I've got three stories to tell you.
These are things that actually happened.
And they are models for scams that you'll probably recognize that you've seen a lot.
So the first is a network admin job scam.
This is where a company says, hey, we're a training school for this major corporation,
this name, and we've got it all over the walls, and you come in, you pay us some money, and
then we'll train you for a few months, and then we'll place you guaranteed in a job with
this big name company.
And you could help administer their new emerging networks.
And the way the scam actually worked, and this happened all over the U.S. and in Europe
some, is that this company would, you know, maybe do a little bit of training, sometimes
they would keep putting you off, and then when the time came for you to have the job,
they would tell you to go to the headquarters of the company.
And this is a real company.
So you go to the headquarters, and the hiring manager there says, we have no idea what the
school is, we have no affiliation with them, there is no guaranteed job, I don't know what
you're talking about.
And, of course, by then, the school has either skipped town, or they are able to just keep
pushing people off.
The next one is, and we see this a lot in terms of wire fraud, is where you have international
banks, in this case, banks in Paris and London, and then somebody goes in and tries to pose
as another person who owns an account at one of these international banks and says, hey,
I'm overseas, here's who I am, I got robbed, I need to get some money, so I need you to
wire it to me at this address, and this would be somewhere, in this case, it was in Turkey.
And then, you know, that social engineering, bypassing their checks and being able to get
money out of somebody else's account by posing as them, identity fraud.
And the third story is on an actual wiretap.
This was a set of gentlemen in India, and they went and put a wiretap into the communications
network, and what they were doing is they were capturing any communications that had
to do with the sale of narcotics.
And what they would do is they would manipulate the price market by saying, oh, this is how
much this person sold to this person for in this quantity, and they're able to manipulate
the market that way.
So does anybody have a guess for about the dates when these scams started cropping up?
The late 1800s.
So these were all telegram fraud.
So you can recognize that these are still scenarios that go on today with modern networks,
but people were doing them way, way back then on the telegrams and the electronic telegram
switching.
So that is to say, what has been is what will be, and what has been done is what will be
done, and there is nothing new under the sun.
So any law enforcement agency will tell you that there are lots of new technologies coming
out and lots of new tools, but in general, the motivations and the ways that criminals
operate tend to repeat in certain patterns.
All right.
So now let's jump into the 60s with peace, love, and purchasing fraud.
And this was pre-internet, of course, but there were some sets of mini-networks, mostly
between retailers or manufacturers and their supply chain.
And what they wanted to do is, as much as they could, get people out of the equation.
So they set up what are called electronic data interchanges.
So you would have like a supplier of hard drives, and through the EDI system, they would
get a purchase order from the producer of computers that needs the hard drives.
So these purchase orders and the invoice and the payment would all go through the EDI network,
and the hard drives would be shipped.
The problem with this is that it was still pretty error-prone.
So a lot of employees had access to the system on both sides, and they were able to manipulate
purchase orders and invoices to either embezzle funds or to steal items without it being noticed
because they could change the number of items that's shown as shipped.
So to combat this, one of the first sets of network security controls were these external
controls set up with value-added networks.
And what this did is it made sure that any employee attempting to tamper with the communications
in the EDI system would be locked out and flagged, and the changes that they made would
be discarded.
And this was some of the first instances of really outsourcing risk, is they would let
this third-party value-added networks deal with all of the transactions.
All right, so let's go to the next decade.
This is the age of disco.
I'm sure all of you are familiar with ARPANET.
This is when it first really started coming about, and also banks and telecom systems
started having pretty extensive networks as well.
About 1969, 1970, we start seeing massive organized crime start perpetrating network
and electronic fraud.
One of the major cases was the inventor of the blue box.
Does anybody not know what a blue box is?
What a blue box is, is it allows you to generate a certain set of tones that allow you in the
old phone network to be able to go ahead and make free long-distance calls.
So there was this crime syndicate based in Las Vegas.
I'm sure you can guess which crime syndicate it was.
One of their major businesses was bookmaking, or taking bets.
So they had to use the phone a lot, and a lot of it was long-distance to New Jersey
and New York and Chicago.
So they made a deal with Al Gilbertson to go ahead and produce a whole bunch of these,
so they drastically reduced their costs in their betting industry by not having to pay
for long-distance fees, which back then was just ridiculous.
In the next year, John Draper found that the Captain Crunch whistle that you got from
the Captain Crunch cereal during that time was able to perfectly produce the 2600 hertz
tone.
So this was essentially a blue box and a whistle.
It would allow you to just bring the whistle up to the phone, make that noise and get your
free long-distance call.
And in the same year, Esquire published an expose on phreaking, and they also published
blue box instructions, which for the time was really dangerous for them to do, because
it would get them in a lot of legal hot water.
Luckily, they got away with it.
Other media outlets like Frack, we'll talk about later, did not get away so easily.
And I'm talking now about phone phreaking, which is committing fraud on the telecom networks.
In the 70s is when it really started launching and becoming mainstream, but this had been
going on since the 50s.
And one of the major pioneers in that, Joy Bubbles, we're coming up on his 10th death
anniversary, so I just want to give him a shout out, tell him I miss your stories.
Yeah, he used to run regular call-in storylines where you would call into his conference line
and he would tell you stories about his adventures through the old telecom networks and, you
know, early movings through those and hacking through the systems, and it was just super
interesting.
So moving on to the next year, 1972, this was the first case that we know of, of using
the internet to purchase and sell drugs.
So some Stanford students in the artificial intelligence lab, the artificial intelligence
lab was allocated a certain number of ARPANET accounts and they started using these accounts
to set up a small transaction of marijuana to their counterparts at MIT.
And mostly this was because we can do it, they did it.
It wasn't a large amount, it was mostly for proof of concept, but it was the first instance
that we have of that.
The real precursor to Silk Road, I would say.
In 1973, we started seeing the first cases of massive financial fraud using electronics.
Equity Funding Corporation of America, they were one of the first companies to move all
of their bookmaking and all of their accounting into computers in electronic form.
And they were perpetrating fraud, and this was across the board.
This was the C-level, the upper management, the middle management, they were all in on it.
And finally an outside company came in, an early Deloitte, you would say, and audited
and found that they had been doing this since 1964, and it was just, you know, probably
one of the largest early fraud schemes for electronic networks.
Also in the same year, a chief teller at New York's Dime Savings Banks was caught
using a computer to embezzle over $1.5 million.
He was caught, so they were able to reverse those transactions.
But again, this was one of the first and largest cases using a computer to steal funds.
So now we'll start looking at the proto-darknets.
These are darknets that were darknet by early definition, but weren't built to be a darknet.
So when we had ARPANET that started cropping up between the U.S. government and between
different universities around the country, there started to crop up other networks outside
of it.
Now, for security reasons, since ARPANET was military research, they would push out information
to these other networks, but those other networks could not respond back to ARPANET.
So they were called in the 1970s darknets, because they couldn't talk to ARPANET.
And some of these would, some of them would die, of course, out of not being maintained
or not enough funds, but the ones that did stay around, those are what essentially became
the core of the internet going forward.
So the 80s and 90s, this was when everybody started getting access to the internet, and
it became a real wild west, because it's also where early e-commerce and early electronic
communications really started booming, and there wasn't a whole lot in the way of security
to go along with it.
We started seeing the rise of hacker collectives, instead of just being, you know, single people
that were perpetrating fraud or crime electronically, we started to see groups really start to
form cohesively.
Some of the big names that came out of this era was Masters of Deception, Legion of Doom,
Chaos Computer Club, which is still going strong, Cult of the Dead Cow, they're still
hobbling along, Loft Heavy Industries, most of those guys you can still find in the Boston
area, and if you go to any of the conferences there, they'll crop up, Firm, and then the
Chinese Honker Union was probably the largest out of all of these collectives.
We also started seeing hacking gain massive media exposure, and this is where we started
to see the term hacking be conflated with cracking, where early on, hacking was just
about discovery and about finding out how systems work, and what you could do to them
to make them operate in different ways, and it was about intellectual curiosity.
And then now the term started to be taken on by the media and used to mean mostly illegal
or damaging acts that were using computers.
So of course War Games, Sneakers, and the Hackers movies really pushed a lot of this
to the forefront of people's minds, and many governments, banks, and large name companies
were hacked or had their web presence impersonated for phishing attempts or things like that.
Again, the security was just abysmal at this point.
There were a lot of telecom and TV stream hijacks too.
One of the most famous ones for the TV streaming would be the satellite Sky TV, it was one
of the first satellite TV setups, and that stream got hijacked multiple times.
They had this back and forth battle with a hacking group.
And then of course the overpowering TV stream interruption in Chicago, which nobody knows
to this day who actually did it, but it was pretty impressive.
We also saw a lot of both readers and journalists starting to become more technically adept
so that they could stomach this more technical sort of reporting.
And then of course we saw massive government responses to this new threat.
In 1981, Interpol held their first training seminar for investigators of computer crime,
and a lot of different law enforcement agencies created their computer task forces out of
this seminar.
In 1984, the U.S. introduced Comprehensive Crime Control Act, which included a specific
component for computer-related crime.
That was expanded later into the 1986 Computer Fraud and Abuse Act, which is a horrible,
horrible law.
It is very, very broad, and it's just been used extensively from then until now in very
abstract fashions.
Also in the same year, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, they
published their recommendations on combating computer-related crime.
And in 1989, this is probably one of the most important ones from that era, the Council
of Europe released their recommendations of 1989, and this was the base framework for
most Europeans' computer crime laws.
In 1990, based off of that, the U.K. released their Computer Misuse Act, and in 1994, I'm
going to butcher this, I'm very sorry, Poznania hosted the Legal Aspects of Computer-Related
Abuse Conference.
Again, that was backed by the Council of Europe, and a lot of task force either grew or came
out of that directly.
And then in 1997, the Polish Penal Code of 1997 was incorporated, and that added a whole
bunch of computer-related fraud and crime recommendations.
In 1998, the G8 set up a 24-7 hotline for high-tech crime investigation.
A lot of law enforcement agencies didn't have the payroll to be able to take on a computer
expert, so with this hotline, regular detectives were able to call in and get expert advice
from the experts they had on staff.
All right, so now we move from the proto-darknets to the quasi-darknets, and these are quasi-darknets
in that you couldn't just go to a search engine and find them or find the content about them.
They weren't built with privacy in mind, they didn't have encryption ingrained, anything
like that, but they were secretive in that you had to know directly where you were connecting
to and you had to have specialized software to do so.
The bulletin board system.
So these are actually still around, mostly for nostalgia reasons, but they are where
we really start seeing this network-based cybercrime groups really starting to communicate
and share knowledge and starting to set up small mini-marketplaces.
So typically, if you heard somebody talking about or you read about an elite BBS, this
was a bulletin board system that was usually closed.
You had to apply for a membership so they could make sure you're not a Fed or you're
not a noob or something like that.
They were very elitist.
And most of the discussions centered around wares, freaking, hacking, cracking, credit
card fraud, ID fraud, things like that.
One of the major groups that came out of this is Razer 1911, they're still around, still
going strong.
Fairlight also came out of this.
And these are groups that would regularly, like, I mean, right as it came out, crack
software and then make it available to the public for free.
Also shout out to Polish Group.
So out of that cracking scene came the demo scene.
This was using low-bit, low-res hardware and software to create graphics and music and
intro videos.
And Accelerate was one based in Poland, and they were pretty big on the scene.
So throw out to them.
And of course there's going to be law enforcement reprisals, right?
So in 1990, it's what was called the Great Hacker Crackdown, and the largest of these
series of global operations was Operation Sun Devil, and this was the FBI in tandem
with the Secret Service and a lot of other law enforcement around the globe, they were
targeting specifically these elite BBSs and the frack e-zine that produced a lot of the
how-to hacking guides at that time.
This was sort of the proto-2600.
And this had a massive chilling effect.
A lot of elite BBSs shut down of their own accord because they didn't want to have the
heat, and we started to see the next few years a real decrease in BBS use.
And of course the crackdown was one reason, but we also saw massive speed increases, which
made the internet more appealing, because it had sub boards, hubs and chats, and you
could have multiple services with just one connection, where with the BBS you had to
have multiple lines to connect to multiple BBSs.
Also around the same time, but a little later in starting, Usenet newsgroups.
Still around.
If somebody tells you that it's a great place to get pirated software, don't, because it's
very easy to track, ISPs just can sit there and look at it.
And it really was where we started first seeing massive spam campaigns.
And also sporgery came out of this.
This is spam campaigns that induce forgery.
They act like they're being sent from somebody else.
Somebody you might trust.
And then we also started to see out of these spam campaigns large-scale bot wars between
the spammers and the admins.
The first iteration of this was the spam bots versus the cancel bots.
The admins would set up cancel bots to try and automatically catch and destroy the spam
bots.
And then this evolved into the spam bots also having forged cancel requests.
So when they got hit by a cancel bot, they would go in and cancel the entire newsgroup.
And so the admins, to combat that, they would set in aliasing out bots, which would whenever
that was triggered, they would completely black hole wherever the bots were coming from.
And then it was this constant arms race and back and forth.
About 1994 is when we started to see a massive decline in these newsgroups.
And AOL gets a lot of the heat for this, because in 93, it was the endless September.
This was where they really did a huge push to get lots of users and lots of users using
their Usenet newsgroups.
So there was a massive influx of noobs on the Usenet groups, and these little communities
that had built themselves and were pretty cohesive were now just getting flooded by
people who didn't really know what they were doing, were just posting willy-nilly, and
there was a lot of mess there.
And the communities were broken up in a lot of ways.
There was also a lot of disk and bandwidth usage that was increasing, so ISPs started
to look at it and say, this isn't really worth it for us to host these anymore, it just costs
too much.
And then, of course, around the same time, the New York Attorneys General really started
a massive anti-Usenet campaign, because there were groups that were trading in child pornography
and child abuse images.
So a lot of ISPs after that just shut off their Usenet service, so they didn't even
have to worry about law enforcement.
One of the tools that a lot of these spammers used, this one was hands down the most famous
one, Hipcrime's News Agent.
And what this did is it allowed any user to pose as an administrator for a newsgroup.
You could auto-cancel any postings, you can replace the body of any message, which allowed
you to do, of course, more targeted spamming.
And whenever one of your posts were removed, it would automatically repost it for you.
Also, it just gave various admin powers, like being able to kick people out or add people,
things like that.
All right.
IRC.
Oh, man.
I spent way too much time on IRC.
So IRC was like drama city.
There were massive forks, you know, down net from F net from one of the earliest IRC nets.
Lots of nick collisions, people taking over other people's names.
Lots of forced net splits, this is where you cause the network to actually be split, usually
through load balancing and across geographies.
And then you could take over operation of a channel by forcing a net split.
There was, of course, a lot of sharing of wares, music, movies, scanned books, lots
of pornography, malware, bots, and actually drug-related sales channels.
And there were a lot of games that we would play.
Like Spot the Fed.
Of course, everybody called everybody else a fed whenever they got in an argument.
Mute the noob.
If somebody was like, how can I hack or can you help me change my grades or something
like that, they would get muted.
And then red flag keyword seeding.
This was way before Edward Snowden.
This is a game we would play in that whenever we were talking to each other, we would just
seed our conversations with red flag words for the NSA.
And these were words like bomb or terrorist or just in the middle of our sentences.
And looking back on it, it was really dumb, but it was fun.
And of course, along with the quasi-darknets are the peer-to-peer networks.
These were focused on file sharing.
There was no web component to these in that you couldn't have a site.
And they weren't really privacy oriented, but they were separate and overlay networks
for the internet.
And I'm sure a lot of you recognize some of these.
And I'm sure a lot of you got malware from some of these.
The one I missed the most was the community for Soul Seek.
That's the little blue bird.
I found so much great new music from around the globe and little small people who produced
their own music would get on there.
It was just wonderful.
Sorry, a little aside there.
Also, I can't mention quasi-darknets without mentioning Sneakernet.
So Sneakernets are mostly found in developing countries, but a lot of developed countries
in certain areas still have active Sneakernets.
And this is where you're not actually using the internet or a connected network, but you're
hand trading data or you're moving it from phone to phone by using a close connection.
And Cuba has a huge one, Mexico has one, a number of different places in South America.
China has a gigantic one.
And there are a few in the northwest of the U.S. and in California, but those are more
like hipster, we're doing it because we can.
And this leads us into the first crypto wars.
This was all about intelligence gathering, containment of the communist threat, and
also the rise of e-commerce and e-commerce protection.
So of course this was the Cold War, which I don't think we ever left.
And COCOM was established after World War II.
This is the Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls.
And one of the important things about this, oh, by the way, Poland was one of the 17 members
along with the U.S., but one of the really important changes here is that they listed
cryptography as a munitions under export control, so that cryptography was essentially equated
with a weapon.
In the early to mid-1990s, there was growing international e-commerce, and they wanted
to protect their customers and their transactions, so they wanted to start using cryptography,
of course.
And there was a lot of lobbying that went into that, and there were eventually relaxations
of the encryption export controls, not adequate relaxations, because it left people having
to use really weak encryption regimes, but it was better than nothing.
Also special call out to the efforts by Netscape and the PGP project.
They were major, major voices in that move.
And in 1996, the Wassenaar arrangement, this replaced COCOM, and it made some changes to
how encryption and cryptography was listed in the export controls.
So there was a general software note that gave exceptions for mass market and public
domain cryptography, but it wasn't widely adopted.
Australia, France, New Zealand, Russia, and the United States completely disregarded it
and continued the tight control on crypto export.
In 1998, there was a series of revisions to the Wassenaar agreement that made for free
for export symmetric crypto up to 56 bits, asymmetric crypto up to 512, and subgroup-based
crypto like EC up to 112 bits.
Also, mass market symmetric cryptography up to 64 bits was then made free for export.
Of course, to us now, with the computer power that we have, these numbers seem like a pittance.
But at that time, they were better than nothing, of course.
And then export of all other crypto regimes required a special license.
All right.
Clear net markets.
So quick rundown.
These are the predecessors to the dark net markets, but they weren't on special encrypted
dark nets with privacy as a focus.
In 2000, the counterfeit library was a diploma mill and ID fraud resources market.
In 2001, a huge forum, Carter Planet, lots of especially Eastern European users, but
also Western users.
There was a major focus there on credit card fraud.
And then out of that came Shadow Crew, which got a lot of media attention.
And that evolved from the counterfeit library and Carter Planet, and they instituted something
that wasn't seen before.
It was a verified vendor service.
So you could tell whether you could trust a vendor or not.
But if that vendor paid the admins enough money, it didn't matter.
They dealt mostly in stolen data, credit cards, ID fraud, and guides on how to do these things.
Between 2003 and 2005, there was a major global law enforcement crackdown on these clear net
markets.
Operation Firewall and Operation Anglerfish were the two largest, arguably.
And there were lots and lots of forum shutdowns.
But of course, inevitably, when you shut down the few large concentrated markets, it just
causes a whole bunch of other smaller ones to crop up.
So one of these out of all the new ones that cropped up was Carter's market.
The admin of that, Iceman or Max Butler, some of you may have heard of him, he was going
around to all the smaller markets and hacking them, stealing their databases, and forcibly
merging them with his so that people had to log into his website.
And from 2007 to now, most of these fraud forums don't last a year.
They're hacked or shut down by law enforcement.
So it's this constant whack-a-mole for fraud forums now.
Law enforcement and researchers can't just go to one or two forums and do the research
that they need or be able to pick and choose the big fish.
They have to deal with up and down markets all the time.
So in order to facilitate these markets, we started seeing the introduction of digital
currencies.
These started with the backed by gold currencies.
They were pegged to the gold standard.
E-gold was one of the first ones.
Pecunix, iGolder, those were the three largest ones.
By now, they're all effectively defunct.
And then we started to see when those went down, Liberty Reserve really just took over
the entire market.
They were dubbed the black market bank, very popular in criminal forums, and they were
involved in lots of large-scale money laundering from huge bank thefts, drug trades, things
like that.
And then we saw the move to cryptocurrencies.
There are a couple out there.
And this is actually from about six months ago, so there are even more than this.
Of course, the biggest one, Bitcoin, it was released in 2009 by who knows.
It's currently the largest by market value and the primary darknet market currency.
But it does have an open ledger with full transaction visibility, so if anybody ever
tells you that Bitcoin is anonymous, smack them.
So one of the other alt-currencies that came out of Bitcoin was Litecoin.
It was a fork of the Bitcoin code.
It was released in 2011 by Charlie Lee, and it is now the fourth largest by market value,
and some darknet markets will accept Litecoin.
Ethereum is one of the fast risers.
It was released in 2015, second largest market value.
It is much more complex than Bitcoin, as it provides a decentralized Turing-complete virtual
machine and its own coding language for it to be developed into other applications and
wrappers and things like that for other blockchain-related activities.
One of the new kids on the scene that's really blowing up, Monero, this was a cryptocurrency
that was built with privacy in mind.
It uses the Cryptonote protocol, and right now it's the sixth largest, but it's also
the fastest-growing cryptocurrency, and it's gaining acceptance among a number of darknet
markets.
All right, so now we're at the modern darknet market, or modern darknets.
These are the darknets that were specifically made to be darknets, privacy-oriented.
Some of the first ones, they had no website component, like you couldn't build a website
on it.
It was just file-sharing, chat, communication, that sort of thing.
The three largest to come out of that, OneSwarm, Tribbler, and Retroshare.
Retroshare is defunct.
OneSwarm is still kind of hobbling along.
And then we have the actual darknet markets that have site components.
There's Freenet, a Riffle project from MIT, of course Tor, Netsukuku, which you'd think
was out of Japan.
No, that's out of Italy.
I2P, huge, Nuenet, and Zeronet.
Tor, as conspiracy theorists like to point out very loudly, it was originally a US Naval
Research Lab and DARPA project, but then was released publicly in 2002.
It uses multi-layered encryption, Onion encryption, aimed for anonymous communication.
It is definitely the largest for darknet traffic, and the largest platform for darknet markets.
Freenet was specifically built to focus on censorship-resistant communication and free
speech for those who would be targeted by oppressive regimes or by censorship of any
form.
It uses a key-based routing protocol to go ahead and have anonymity, but also keep the
nodes up in case other ones get taken down.
I2P was based on a very similar code base as Freenet.
It was released in 2003.
It can also act as an anonymous network layer for other protocols, like you can run FTP
through it, the other normal protocols.
It uses an extension of the Onion routing, it uses what's called Garlic routing, which
is a series of, I guess, nodes of Onion routing sources, instead of just one large Onion routing
schema.
Nuenet, this one, of course, it's open source, new.
In order for it to be a darknet, it requires the friend-to-friend protocol network topology
turned on, and it really started gaining popularity after the Edward Snowden Prism leaks.
Netsukuku is kind of in limbo right now.
It's version 2.0 in development, but what's neat about it is it has its own custom routing
protocol and its own DNS system, which have some pretty neat features in and of themselves.
It's still in alpha, and there hasn't really been any large-scale testing, but it's a great
idea.
Zeronet was based on Bitcoin crypto and the BitTorrent network together.
